chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: This section describes how to install corinet on your system. There is no automated installer but the installation process is quite straightforward and should work equally well on different operating systems. corinet has so far been tested on Microsoft Windows, Linux and Apple Mac.

listitem.para: Make a directory to hold all files for the corinet project.

Define an environment variable CORINETROOT (in capitals) pointing to this directory. On Windows, this can be done via "Control Panel/System/Advanced/Environment Variables". On Unix-based systems this can be achieved by defining a setenv command in a file that is sourced at the start of your session. Please refer to the help system of your Unix distribution for more information.

Make a $CORINETROOT/bin directory and add it to your search path. On Windows, this can be done in "Control Panel/System/Advanced/Environment Variables". On Unix-based systems it is done similarly to the previous step.

corinet uses the Xerces-C XML parser library (version 2.7.0 or later). Download from The Apache XML Project and follow the build or installation instructions. When the build or installation was successful, do the following:
On Windows, copy xerces-c.lib and xerces-c_x_y.dll to the $CORINETROOT/bin directory. x and y are the version numbers of the Xerces release you are installing (e.g., 2 and 7 for version 2.7.0). If the .lib file has been created as xerces-c_2.lib be sure to rename it.
On Linux, copy libxerces-c.so.xy.0 to a directory in the LIB_SEARCH_PATH, e.g. /usr/lib.
On other Unix systems requirements are similar: a '.so' or '.sl' file included in the search path of the dynamic loader.
